intro: Passerina anthylloides, commonly known as the narrow-leaf pasqueflower, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of western North America. It is a member of the Ranunculaceae family, characterized by its showy, early spring blooms. The plant typically grows in alpine and subalpine habitats, preferring well-drained soils and full sun exposure. Its leaves are narrow and lance-shaped, often with a hairy texture, while its flowers are usually pink or purple with five petals. Passerina anthylloides is known for its resilience to harsh environmental conditions and its ecological importance as a food source for pollinators.
